entry.title: Police: 3 Killed in Baltimore Shooting; No Motive Released
Psych firm that screens Baltimore cops under review
entry.summary: Baltimore Police declined to answer any questions about PCA, referring all queries to City Hall.

entry.title: Psych firm that screens Baltimore cops under review
entry.summary:
FILE - This May 1, 2015, file photo provided by the Baltimore Police Department shows Lt. Brian Rice, one of the police officers charged with felonies in the death of Freddie Gray.

The psychological firm paid to evaluate Baltimore police, including Rice, Psychology Consultants Associated, has been reprimanded by the state police for cutting corners in its mental health screenings of officers.

Baltimore's law department and inspector general are also investigating the firm's assessments of city police officers, said Kevin Harris, a spokesman for the city.

As part of his contract with the Baltimore City Police Department, Sachs assessed the mental health and fitness for duty of officers who were removed from active duty due to psychological problems.

Michael A. Wood, a retired Baltimore police sergeant who said he wrote the department's medical policy, said Rice "absolutely would have had a fitness for duty evaluation, and would have been referred to PCA. It would have been required."

entry.title: Baltimore homicide uptick: Anti-crime partnership launched
entry.summary:
U.S. Rep. Elijah Cummings, front center, and other elected officials announce the start of the Baltimore Federal Homicide Task Force, Monday, Aug. 3, 2015, in Baltimore.

The homicide rate in Baltimore began to skyrocket in May, when the city saw 42 homicides in a single month.

entry.title: Maryland governor to close Baltimore detention center
entry.summary: The ACLU and the Baltimore-based Public Justice Center last month called on a federal judge to reopen a lawsuit against the state of Maryland over what the agencies described as substandard conditions.

entry.title: Maryland governor to close Baltimore detention center
entry.summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan, right, poses at Baltimore City Detention Center, Thursday, July 30, 2015, in Baltimore, at the end of a news conference to announce his plan to immediately shut down the jail.

entry.title: Maryland governor to close Baltimore detention center
Baltimore boy has first bilateral hand transplant on child
Police: Officer shoots, wounds man in Baltimore
entry.summary: Police say an officer shot a man in the face in southwest Baltimore after the man ran his car into a cruiser.

entry.title: Baltimore officials release thousands of pages of documents related to unrest after Gray death
entry.summary: BALTIMORE - Baltimore officials have released thousands of pages of documents related to unrest following Freddie Gray's death.

entry.title: Former Oriole Markakis returns to Baltimore with Braves
entry.summary:
He thought he would spend his entire career in Baltimore, but the Orioles opted not to match Atlanta's contract offer of $44 million over four years.

His association with Baltimore extended well beyond Camden Yards.

entry.title: Police: Man shot, gravely hurt near site of Baltimore unrest
entry.summary: Police say an 18-year-old man has been shot in the chest near the epicenter of April unrest in west Baltimore.

entry.title: Police: Teen shot, gravely hurt near site of Baltimore unrest after Freddie Gray funeral
entry.summary: A man sleeps on a stoop as police guard the perimeter of the scene of a shooting on Monday, July 27, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Police: Male shot near epicenter of Baltimore unrest
entry.summary: A member of the Baltimore Police Department stands near evidence at the scene of a shooting on Monday, July 27, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Police: Male shot near epicenter of Baltimore unrest
Blackface performer plans fundraiser for officers indicted in death of black man
entry.summary:
Tessa Hill-Aston, president of the Baltimore branch of the NAACP, says the idea is "very distasteful."

Gray's death prompted a wave of arson, looting and open confrontations with riot police in Baltimore in April.

entry.title: Freddie Gray death: blackface fundraiser planned for indicted police officers
entry.summary:
A former Baltimore police officer has said he plans to perform an Al Jolson routine in blackface to raise money for the six Baltimore officers who have been indicted in the death of Freddie Gray.

Michael Davey, an attorney for the Baltimore City Fraternal Order of Police, said officers did not support the fundraiser.

entry.title: In wake of riots and crime spike, Baltimore mayor under fire
entry.summary:
In this photo taken Tuesday, July 21, 2015, Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake stands outside vacant homes before a ceremony to kick off their restoration in Baltimore.

For better or worse, since she sacked Police Commissioner Anthony Batts, the mayor has been alone at the top of a city government that has yet to show how it will repair the strained relationship between police and the people of inner-city Baltimore.

But for many in Baltimore, the memory of how Rawlings-Blake responded to the riots is too raw, and the city's unmet expectations are overwhelming.

entry.title: Mayor challenged by rioting, crime spike and firing of chief faces criticism, competition
entry.summary:
"The people of Baltimore deserve better and we're going to get better," she said then.

The Baltimore Sun questioned Rawlings-Blake's leadership.

entry.title: Man charged with attempted murder after officer stabbed
entry.summary: The stabbing occurred in the lobby of the Varsity Apartments, which houses University of Baltimore students.

entry.title: Man charged with attempted murder after stabbing of Baltimore officer at student apartments
entry.summary: BALTIMORE - A 20-year-old man has been charged with attempted murder after Baltimore police say he stabbed an officer after a domestic dispute inside a student apartment building.
